webTitle: AbbVie's raised proposal for Shire gets board backing

fields.bodyText: A blockbuster £31bn takeover of the London-listed drug company Shire by US rival AbbVie came a step closer on Monday, after Shire's board announced it would back the deal despite concerns over its controversial tax structure. AbbVie has indicated that shifting its tax domicile from the US to the UK is a key part of the logic behind the proposed takeover. The drive to escape a punitive US tax regime, echoing proposals by American peer Pfizer during its failed £69bn attempt to acquire Britain's AstraZeneca earlier this year, had alarmed the Shire board when it rebuffed an AbbVie approach last month. However, those concerns appeared to have abated on Monday when Shire said it would recommend a proposal – the fifth that AbbVie has made – that valued the rare-diseases specialist at £53.20 a share. Shire said: "The board of Shire has indicated to AbbVie that it would be willing to recommend an offer at the level of the revised proposal to Shire shareholders subject to satisfactory resolution of the other terms of the offer." Shire, best known for drugs for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and rare diseases, is an attractive target for AbbVie, which is looking to diversify its product range as well as reduce its tax bill. AbbVie's Humira rheumatoid arthritis drug accounts for 60% of sales but loses patent protection at the end of 2016. If the takeover goes ahead, Illinois-based AbbVie would move its legal address to the UK, cutting its effective corporate tax rate from 22% to 13% by 2016. Analysts at Barclays estimated the move would provide an estimated $1.3bn (£760m) in tax savings by 2020. In a statement last month, the Shire board said AbbVie's tax proposals were risky, amid mounting political opposition in the US to so-called corporate inversions, where companies move their head office abroad to make tax savings. The board said it "had concerns regarding the execution risks associated with the proposed [tax] inversion structure, as AbbVie would redomicile in the UK for tax purposes". Shire's opposition has weakened amid pressure from shareholders, who have called for talks. One analyst said Shire was one of the few outstanding targets for US firms seeking an inversion deal in the wake of the failed Pfizer pursuit. Alistair Campbell, at banking group Berenberg, said there were few other British drugmakers that would suit a tax inversion takeover because shareholders in the target company must own at least 20% of the merged group after the deal is completed. Under the terms of the AbbVie proposal, Shire shareholders would own 25% of the combined firms. "You can't go for small companies," he said. "Glaxo is too big, Astra has had an approach from Pfizer and Shire has now gone." Hull-based Smith & Nephew, Europe's largest maker of artificial joints, has also been seen as a possible target. But US-based rival Stryker has said it would not bid for the company after reports linking it with a deal circulated in May. Elsewhere, Sweden's Meda rejected an improved takeover offer from US generic drugmaker Mylan in April, which could have helped reduce taxes. A takeover of Shire is unlikely to incite the political and public furore that erupted over Pfizer's courtship of AstraZeneca. Shire was founded in the UK, but is managed in Boston, headquartered in Dublin and generates most of its sales in the US. It employs fewer than 500 people in the UK – out of a 5,000-strong workforce – and has a small research and development staff in Britain. AstraZeneca, has 2,000 R&D employees in the UK alone and Pfizer's pledge to secure R&D jobs in the wake of a takeover was not enough to quell political opposition to its proposals. The AstraZeneca row prompted ministers to draw up proposals that would see foreign companies hit with penalties if they broke promises over jobs and investment once they had taken over a UK business. Cable said: "There will be cases where there are vital national interests, in this case large-scale investment of R&D. The question is how you protect it. What the government did then [during Pfizer 's proposed takeover] was to engage in negotiations to seek assurances. Where we now have to strengthen that is to make sure that with any commitments made there is no wriggle room." Shares in Shire closed up 0.7% at £49.03.

webTitle: Young adults 'bearing brunt of recession', says leading thinktank

fields.standfirst: Institute for Fiscal Studies finds people in age group have found jobs hard to find
fields.body:
Britain's young workers have suffered above average falls in pay, have found it harder to find a job, and in many cases have been forced to stay living with their parents, according to a leading thinktank that conducted research into official figures from 2008.

The Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) found that average incomes for people in their 20s fell by 13% between 2007/08 and 2012/13, compared with an average fall for all workers of 10%, and only 7% for 31- to 59-year-olds.

Finding a job proved to be a difficult task for those in their 20s, with the employment rate for 22- to 30-year-olds fell by four percentage points during the five years to April 2013, while the rate for the over-30s remained at pre-crisis levels.

"Young adults have borne the brunt of the recession," said Jonathan Cribb, a research economist at the IFS, and an author of the report.

"Pay, employment and incomes have all been hit hardest for those in their 20s. A crucial question is whether this difficult start will do lasting damage to their employment and earnings prospects".

The IFS examined the DWP's Households Average Income study in tandem with the Office for National Statistics' labour force survey to arrive at the new figures.

It found that young workers able to get on the housing ladder were cushioned by ultra low interest rates.

A quarter forced to live at home with heir parents also had higher than average disposable incomes, though the need for parental subsidies is likely an indication of the low pay rates and often insecure working practices on offer to younger workers.

Poor children have also suffered since the financial crash and through the recession that followed.

The IFS said the official measure of child deprivation rose by 300,000 children in 2012–13, and has generally been on an upwards trajectory since 2007–08.

Child deprivation is highest in London, which also has the highest rate of income poverty, once its higher housing costs are taken into account.

webTitle: IMF warns that eurozone recovery is weak; QE may be needed – business live

fields.standfirst:
Rolling business and financial news, as International Monetary Fund renews pressure on the European Central Bank to consider quantitative easing

  • IMF: Euro recovery is weak and uneven...
  • ...But QE might actually push up euro, IMF says
  • Citi agrees $7bn penalty over toxic mortgage loans
  • Eurostat: industrial output slides 1.1% in May
  • Russia cold-shouldered at Farnborough
  • Wonga appoints new chairman

Earlier: UK pharmaceutical firm Shire receives a higher takeover approach from US rival AbbVie, valuing it at over £31bn

  • Shire tells City: we're willing to recommend new offer
  • Portuguese bonds recover
fields.body:
8.37pm BST

Mario Draghi tells MEPs: QE is in our mandate

Footnote. Mario Draghi's appearance at the European parliament didn't see too many fireworks (just as well, as I didn't manage to update the blog on my way home).

The ECB president did warn that Europe's recovery could suffer if the euro strengthened.

And he declared that quantitative easing was squarely in the middle of the ECB's mandate -- hours after the IMF urged him to consider it.

And the oddest moment came when Draghi insisted he plans to stay at the ECB. Apparently there's a rumour in the German media that he was considering leaving:

G'nite. GW

5.08pm BST

Afternoon summary

Time for a quick catch-up:

The International Monetary Fund has renewed its call for the eurozone to embark on quantitative easing, warning that the recovery is too fragile.

IMF staff also argued that a new asset-purchase scheme would drive up growth and inflation. But they also suggested that it could potentially cause the euro to strengthen again other currencies – not what Europe needs...

The warning came hours after fresh data showed industrial production in the eurozone slid by 1.1% during May. That suggests the sector may shrink in the last quarter – which would suggest the recovery is faltering, analysts warned.

In the corporate world, US firm AbbVie made another attempt to take over UK drugs firm Shire, after increasing its offer again, to £31.3bn.

Analysts believe it's a fair price. But shares in Shire closed up 0.6% at £49.03, shy of the new offer of £53.20 per share, showing that it's not a done deal yet....

And Citigroup agreed a $7bn settlement to close an investigation into its mortgage-securities business before the financial crash, which wiped out its profits for the last quarter.

The US Attorney General warned that the deal does not indemnify Citi employees from possible legal action in future.

Europe's stock markets bounced back from last week's losses, with the FTSE 100 rising 0.8%.

Here's Nick Fletcher's closing market report: FTSE 100 buoyed by Shire deal and Citigroup figures

Portugal's Espirito Santo conglomerate remains under pressure tonight - shares in Bancl Espirito Santo fell another 8%, and the yield on one set of bonds rose to around 10%.

In the UK, the new chairman of Wonga has vowed to clean up its image. The elderly puppets used in its TV adverts are the first to go....

And the Farnborough Air Show has begun, with Russia's delegation being frozen out over the Ukraine crisis....

...and the prime minister announcing £1.1bn of new defence orders, before having a peek inside the cockpit of an Airbus A35:

Reminder, Mario Draghi is appearing at the European Parliament tonight, from 6.30pm BST (7.30pm CET). It might be webcast here(if I find a better link I"ll post it in the blog).

And I might update the blog once Draghi has spoken..... #promisespromises

Otherwise, back tomorrow.... Goodnight. GW

Updated at 9.41pm BST

5.03pm BST

FTSE 100 gains 0.8% as markets recover

Britain's blue-chip stock index has posted its biggest one day gain since the start of July.

The FTSE 100 closed up 55 points, or +0.85%, at 6746, as City traders shrugged off last week's worries about a crash.

The German DAX rose 1.2%, and the French CAC gained 0.8%.

Chris Beauchamp, Market analyst at IG, says Citigroup's good results (excluding that $7bn hit) helped shares bounce back:

And so another stock market dip appears to have been consigned to the dustbin of history. On Bastille Day traders across the globe have displayed a little of the ardour that so animated those that stormed the infamous prison, while banishing any thoughts of beleaguered Portuguese banks to the back of their mind.

Shire’s coy dalliance with AbbVie has resulted in the UK firm agreeing to a takeover, and it seems that all concerned are quite contented with the outcome.

And that's all the excuse I need to post a few photos from Paris:

Updated at 5.04pm BST

4.25pm BST

Espirito Santo, the saga continues

Pressure continues to build on Portugal's Espirito Santo conglomerate.

Tomorrow, we'll find out whether one of its divisions will repay a €897m loan made three months ago by Portugal Telecom. That transaction has already hurt relations between PT and its Brazilian partners, who didn't know about it.

Theres also suggestions that PT did know that Espirito Santo was in difficulties, but made the loan anyway. More here.

And its bank, Banco Espirito Santo, has now seen its share price fall almost 8% today.

Its bonds have also fallen in value, driving up the yield on notes that mature in 2023 to almost 10% this afternoon. That suggests bond traders are more worried that it might restructure its debts, despite its new management team being rushed in.


4.14pm BST

Incidentally, the IMF report comes just hours before Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, appears before the European parliament to answer MEP's questions.

Draghi has shown irritation before at the Fund's habit of offering advice to the ECB, so tonight's hearing could be quite punchy......

3.53pm BST

Here's Katie Allen's story on the IMF's eurozone report

Eurozone is weak and risks falling into deflation, IMF report warns

3.37pm BST

IMF: QE could actually strengthen the euro

The International Monetary Fund has also warned that the euro could actually rise in value if the European Central Bank launched a quantitative easing programme to fight deflation.

Two senior IMF staffers, Reza Moghadam and Ranjit Teja, have examined whether the European Central Bank should move into QE, and start buying assets with new money.

Their blogpost is here. In it, they suggest QE would stimulate the eurozone's growth rate, saying:

QE is not a panacea or substitute for reforms. But it can push up inflation by raising consumption and investment across the euro area.

QE, they note, is the last weapon in the ECB's monetary toolkit:

QE could improve the supply of bank credit, they suggest (by pushing the value of assets on bank balance sheets), and also increase demand for credit (by raising growth expectations).

Moghadam and Teji see little immediate risk from encouraging more risk taking; anyway, banks have macro-prudential powers if needed.

QE could push down eurozone government bond yields, they suggest (as happened in Japan). And it could make households feel wealthier, by pushing European shares up - having lagged behind Wall Street since the crisis.

But what would it mean for the euro, which is already uncomfortably high? It would probably push down its value, the IMF says. But it might have the opposite effect....

Moghadam and Teji write:

On the currency, QE would likely weaken the euro. Insofar as this raises demand and traded goods prices, it helps tackle the threat from low inflation. This could be an important channel. But depreciation is not inevitable: rising asset prices/economic prospects due to QE may draw capital and appreciate the euro.

And that would not help the ECB stimulate inflation, as imports would become cheaper.....

3.18pm BST

The IMF statement is online here.

3.13pm BST

These quotes from the IMF's report into the eurozone sums up the situation:

“The recovery is weak and uneven. Inflation has been too low for too long, financial markets are still fragmented, and structural gaps persist: these hinder rebalancing and substantial reductions in debt and unemployment.”

“Weakness in banks’ balance sheets and uncertainty about their quality are contributing to fragmentation, constraining the ability and willingness of banks to support credit and investment.”

“Risks to growth are still tilted to the downside. With limited policy space in the near term, further negative shocks – either domestic or external – could undermine financial market sentiment, halt the recovery, and push the economy into lower inflation and even deflation.”

3.09pm BST

The IMF is also warning that the eurozone isn't in a good state to shrug off any further shocks, and urged politicians to resist further austerity:

  • 15:00 - IMF SAYS FURTHER NEGATIVE SHOCKS COULD SOUR MARKET SENTIMENT, HALT RECOVERY, BRING DEFLATION TO EURO ZONE
  • 15:00 - IMF SAYS ANY NEGATIVE GROWTH SHOCKS IN EURO ZONE SHOULD NOT TRIGGER ADDITIONAL AUSTERITY
  • 15:00 - IMF SAYS EURO ZONE NEEDS TO SUPPORT DEMAND, COMPLETE BANKING UNION, ADVANCE STRUCTURAL REFORMS

3.02pm BST

IMF: eurozone recovery is weak; urgent action needed on banks

Breaking: The International Monetary Fund has warned that the recovery in the eurozone is weak and risks falling into deflation, and cut its growth forecast for this year.

My colleague Katie Allen has the details of the IMF's latest mission to the eurozone:

The International Monetary Fund has just released its latest report into the state of the eurozone and it will make daunting reading for policymakers in the single currency bloc.

The Washington-based fund is calling for a raft of actions to shore up the eurozone as it highlights a recovery that is “neither robust nor sufficiently strong” and says the “euro-skeptic” outcome of recent European election outcome poses an additional threat to the single market.

And here are the IMF's key points:

  • The eurozone recovery is weak, its financial markets remain too fragmented and the region risks falling into deflation.
  • Urgent action is needed to repair bank balance sheets and to step up reforms to boost employment.
  • Moves on low inflation from the European Central Bank are welcome but the ECB should be ready to embark on quantitative easing should inflation stay “too low”.

The IMF predicts a long haul ahead. Growth was expected to accelerate only a little next year, to 1.5% from 1.1% in 2014 – a slight downgrade from April’s prediction of 1.2% growth this year.

That outlook compares with the IMF’s forecast for the UK economy to grow 2.9% this year and for the US to expand 2%.

Inflation in the eurozone was seen remaining below the ECB’s target of around 2%. The IMF predicts inflation of 0.7% this year and 1.2% in 2015.

More details and reaction to follow....

2.57pm BST

Goldman Sachs shares are pushing the Dow up, as traders react to Citigroup's results (rather than its ropey World Cup predictions)

2.52pm BST

DING: The Dow just hit a new all-time intraday high:

2.51pm BST

Wall Street follows Europe with rising shares

Over in New York, shares are rallying in early trading in New York.

The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 135 points, or 0.8%, to 17079, mirroring today's gains in Europe, where the FTSE 100 is up 67 points, or 1%.

Citigroup's results appear to have cheered Wall Street. Profits would have been up, if the bank hadn't agreed a $7bn settlement to resolve the investigation into its sale of mortgage-backed securities.

2.41pm BST

City analysts who dared to predict how the World Cup would play out are feeling a little embarrassed today.

Goldman Sachs, for example, boldly predicted Brazil would lift the trophy -- and even after rejigging its forecasts for the knock-out section it reckoned the Netherlands would finish runners-up.

But fair play to Goldman -- they've 'fessed up on Twitter:

I'm sure the German team appreciate the gesture - once they've finished posting selfies with chancellor Merkel, that is....

2.27pm BST

Here's another photo from the Farnborough Air Show, of prime minister David Cameron meeting staff from UK firm Avingtrans.

Cameron also announced £1.1bn of fresh defence spending, including £300m for better radars for Britain's Typhoon fighters, and £800m in new intelligence kit (as previewed this morning)

2.00pm BST

Russian delegates shunned at Farnborough Air Show

The Cold War may be over, but Russian delegates at the Farnborough International Air Show were still given the cold shoulder today.

In a rare move, the British government decided not to issue Russia's delegation with invitations this year, following events in Ukraine and Crimea:

A government spokesperson explained;

"The government has also taken clear action to remove Russia from the list of countries eligible to use open general export licences, in order to discourage Russian attendance at [the show] ... No foreign government representatives attending [Farnborough] as guests of [the UK government] will be escorted around the Russian pavilion by officials."

This prompted Russian deputy prime minister Dmitry Rogozin ordered the country's delegation to pull out . He tweeted:

More here: Russia withdraws delegates from Farnborough air show

But as these photos show, Russian ministers have managed to meet some journalists at a chalet run by state-owned firm Rostec.

Despite the diplomatic tensions, Russian arms companies are still demonstrating at the show.

That includes Rosoboronexport, the Russian state-owned arms firm that supplied attack helicopters and grenade launchers to the Syrian regime.

David Cameron under fire as Syrian regime arms supplier visits UK airshow

1.33pm BST

Traders in New York reckon that AbbVie's shares will fall around 1.8% when trading begins in one hour, after it upped its offer for UK drugs firm Shire to £31.30bn this morning.

Shire's shares are still up in London, gaining around 1.5% to £49.42. That's around 3% below AbbVie's new offer, of £51.30 per share, showing some doubt that the deal will go through.

As explained this morning - Shire's board is now indicating that it could support the deal, but the 'tax-inversion' plan could be scuppered by politicians in Washington.

1.07pm BST

Citi shares are rising in pre-market trading as Wall Street traders digest its results:

1.06pm BST

Citi earnings hit by mortgage settlement

Citigroup is releasing its latest earnings report right now....

And the top line is that the bank achieved earnings of $1.24 per share in the last quarter. That's ahead of forecasts (analysts had expected $1.05 per share)

But that falls to just $0.03 per share once the $7bn cost of settling its mortgage-securities probe is included.

Citi is also reporting that total revenues declined to $19.34bn in the quarter, down from $20.49bn a year ago.

12.46pm BST

Back in the UK, energy producer Drax is celebrating a win at the high court.

Judges overturned the British government's recent decision not to include one of Drax's units at its Yorkshire coal plant in a biomass subsidy scheme.

Shares in Drax jumped 5% following the news, which should help the company convert the polluting plant from burning coal to wood pellets.

Updated at 12.46pm BST

12.24pm BST

US attorney: Citi staff not absolved from criminal charges

It appears that Citi employees could still face legal action, even though the bank has just settled its account with US authorities.

Reuter has snapped a statement from the US Attorney General:

  • US ATTORNEY GENERAL SAYS DOJ ANNOUNCES CIVIL RESOLUTION WITH CITIGROUP TOTALING $7 BLN IN FINES, INCLUDING A CIVIL PENALTY OF $4 BLN
  • U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL SAYS SETTLEMENT WITH CITIGROUP RELATED TO SALE OF SECURITIES THAT WERE BACKED BY TOXIC LOANS
  • US ATTORNEY GENERAL SAYS CITI TRIED TO HID THE DEFECTS OF THE INCREASINGLY RISKY LOANS THEY WERE SECURITIZING
  • US ATTORNEY GENERAL SAYS SETTLEMENT DOES NOT ABSOLVE CITIGROUP OR ITS EMPLOYEES FROM FACING ANY POSSIBLE CRIMINAL CHARGES IN THE FUTURE
  • US ATTORNEY GENERAL SAYS "UNDER THE TERMS OF THIS SETTLEMENT, THE BANK HAS ADMITTED TO ITS MISDEEDS IN GREAT DETAIL"

Updated at 12.25pm BST

12.17pm BST

Michael Corbat, Citigroup's CEO, says the "comprehensive" $7bn settlement means Citi has resolved all the civil investigations related to its mortgage-backed securities business before the crash.

Corbat is now looking forwards:

We believe that this settlement is in the best interests of our shareholders, and allows us to move forward and to focus on the future, not the past.”

12.12pm BST

Citi to pay $7bn to settle mortage-securities probe

Just in: US bank Citi has agreed to a $7bn package of fines and compensation to resolve a probe into its mortgage-backed securities business.

The settlement relates to allegations that Citi misled investors by selling securities linked to toxic loans in the run-up to the 2008 financial crisis.

The bank will pay $4.5bn fines, and provide $2.5bn in "consumer relief" to settle the charges.

City said it will take a $3.8bn pre-tax charge to help cover the penalty.

More to follow...

11.57am BST

Andy Haste's arrival at Wonga comes as another payday lender, called Dollar, is forced to return £700,000 to its customers.

The City watchdog, the Financial Services Authority, said that Dollar, which traded as The Money Shop, had not carried out proper checks to ensure that its borrowers could repay their loans.

It must now contact customers to arrange refunds, or to cut their outstanding balances.

Updated at 12.39pm BST

11.42am BST

Sounds like Andy Haste has got off to a good start at Wonga:

11.41am BST

The new chairman of Wonga has hit the ground running, pledging to consign its frankly unsettling puppets to the bin:

More here: Cuddly puppets axed as Wonga attempts big clean-up

Cuddly??!!


11.29am BST

Wonga's new chairman vows to repair its reputation

Wonga has just named a new chairman -- experienced City figure Andy Haste.

And Haste, the former boss of insurance group RSA, has declared that his priority is to turn the controversial payday lender into a smaller and less profitable business, at least in the short term.

Haste's appointment fills a void at Wonga following the departure of founder Errol Damelin.

The payday loans industry has been rocked by political criticism and increased regulatory scrutiny in recent months, and Haste warned that changes must be made at Wonga to repair its reputation.

He says:

This is a sector that is necessarily undergoing significant change and Wonga will change with it in order to have a sustainable future.

My challenge is to lead that process of change at Wonga to ensure that the business operates responsibly while providing an effective and reliable service for our customers

Haste added...

We will become a more customer focused, and inevitably in the near term, a smaller and less profitable business. However, we are determined to make the necessary changes and serve our customers in the right way, to repair our reputation and become a business with a long-term future and an accepted place in the financial services industry.”

Wonga's shareholders say Haste was "the outstanding choice", and he does bring some City gravitas to the lender.

He is currently the senior independent director of ITV plc and the senior independent deputy chairman of Lloyd’s. He's going to be busy.....

Updated at 11.34am BST

11.15am BST

Reuters: Eurozone industry stumbles in May

And here's Reuters' take on this morning's industrial output figures (details start here):

Eurozone industrial production dropped sharply in May with the energy sector the only one to thrive, data showed on Monday, highlighting the fragile state of the bloc's recovery.

Output in the 18 countries sharing the euro dropped 1.1% on the month in May, following a 0.7% rise in April, the European Union's statistics office Eurostat said.

Analysts surveyed by Reuters had expected a 1.2% monthly fall in May. Compared with the same period in 2013, factory gate output grew in line with market expectations by 0.5% after a 1.4% rise in April.

The month-on-month decline was led by a 2.4% fall in production of intermediate goods - such as parts used for cars. There was a 2.2% drop in the production of non-durable items such as food or cosmetics.The energy sector was the only one to grow, showing a 3% increase after a 1.2% growth in April.

Industrial production in the euro zone's three biggest economies - Germany, France and Italy - fell month-on-month. Germany saw the biggest drop since May 2013 with a 1.4% fall.France, with a 1.3% decline, recorded the steepest fall in production since June 2013 and Italy's production registered its worst performance since November 2012 with a 1.2% drop.

There is now a grave danger that the sector contracted in the second quarter thereby limiting Eurozone GDP growth.

Industrial output across the euro area fell by 1.1% month-on-month in May, which means output was just 0.5% higher than a year ago.

Eurostat reported that the production of intermediate goods fell by 2.4%; non-durable consumer goods was down by 2.2%.

Durable consumer goods production fell by 1.8% and capital goods (heavy duty machinery) dropped by 0.5%.

We all realise that Aldi is the EasyJet of the supermarket world (Report, 1 July), but most shoppers do not realise how basic its services are and how this impacts on the disabled. Aldi sells food cheaply but does not offer any of the services normally found in supermarkets such as papers, stamps etc, making them more like the old wholesale warehouses that used to sell to the public.

Being disabled, I have have been unable to find wheelchairs or seating at Aldi. In my experience, checkout assistants do not normally help people to pack at the checkouts. They seem to be paid on how fast they scan the goods and cannot scan and pack as they process the items. Some assistants try to help; others do not. It's obvious why people shop at Aldi, but I'm not sure it should be compared to other fully featured supermarkets. It changes its products frequently and something you like may not be there next week – and it has a very limited range of vegetarian food.
Phillip Brown
Westbury, Wiltshire

webTitle: Wonga in a hurry to make amends but new chief is a good hire

fields.standfirst: City bigwig Andy Haste will probably turn around the payday lender's fortunes and dropping the puppets is a good first step
fields.body:
Hire a City bigwig, shoot the puppets and bow humbly in front of the regulators. In the face of a dreadful public reputation and a scandal over fake legal letters, Wonga's venture capital owners have chosen pragmatism.

They had no alternative, of course. Dreams of flogging their company for a pretty technology-style valuation are in tatters. The game now is about earning the right to operate by adapting to a tougher regulatory regime for payday lenders.

Andy Haste is a good hire as chairman. He is a member of the financial establishment – a former chief executive of RSA and now the deputy chairman of insurance market Lloyd's of London – and so has a personal reputation on the line. He will cost £500,000 a year, plus a yet-to-be-decided equity cut, but the venture capitalists will regard that as decent value if he helps Wonga survive.

Dropping the puppets on day one is a smart way for Haste to demonstrate better corporate intentions. Wonga's boasts about being a "responsible" lender always came across as self-serving nonsense while the company used fun-seeking grandparents to whistle the joys of high-interest loans. There is nothing cheerful about borrowing at annualised interest rates of 5,000%, even for short periods.

Haste says Wonga will be a "smaller and less profitable business" in the future. You bet it will. The Financial Conduct Authority will soon impose a cap on the rate of interest payday lenders can charge. Given the high default rates, we are yet to discover what interest rate the likes of Wonga require to earn a commercial return on capital. Certainly, the profits of £62.5m that Wonga made in 2012 won't be repeated soon.

A cleaned-up Wonga probably does have a place in the financial services industry. There will always be demand for short-term credit, so it is best to ensure it happens within a tightly regulated environment. But what will replace the irritating puppets? If Haste wanted to adopt an honest advertising line, he could try this: "Borrow from us only if you are truly desperate."

webTitle: Scots and shares - business school weighs up the 'Scotsie 100'

fields.bodyText: What if instead of Buy Buy Footsie, it was Buy Buy Scotsie? As the vote on independence approaches, a report shows that a notional index of 100 Scottish companies currently listed on the London Stock Exchange would have grown by 5.7% in real terms (with dividends reinvested) since 1955. But it would have been outperformed by stocks from the rest of the UK, which rose 6.8% over the same period. The difference is due to the predominance of financial companies in the "Scotsie 100", and in particular the near collapse of Royal Bank of Scotland and HBOS in the banking crisis. Without this, it would have outperformed the UK index by a small margin. The report, by the London Business School and consultancy Walbrook Economics, uses the location of a company's headquarters to judge whether it is Scottish or not. Apart from financial companies such as banks and investment trusts, the Scotsie index is dominated by utilities, and oil and gas companies. The largest are energy business SSE, insurer Standard Life, Royal Bank of Scotland, FTSE100 engineer Weir Group and Aggreko, the generator manufacturer. The research was driven by the question of whether Scotland should set up its own stock exchange – something which existed until 1973 – as other countries have done after gaining independence. If all Scotsie 100 stocks chose to list on a new Scottish bourse, it would rank 28th in the world. This, says the report, is the same as the Scottish football team's post-World Cup Fifa ranking. But the report concludes: "It will be a tough challenge to attract the Scotsie 100 companies away from the large liquid international London exchange on which they are already listed along with their FTSE imprimatur. It would make more sense for Scotland to continue to rely for its stock market services on the LSE and AIM." Paul Marsh, of London Business School, said there was uncertainty over the terms of separating from the UK in the event of a yes vote in the 18 September referendum. But he added: "We believe that investors in Scotsie 100 stocks should not be unduly concerned, nor should they be making contingency plans to rebalance their portfolios. "To some extent, they are protected by the fact that both companies and individuals can re-domicile if necessary. There would also be a period of at least 18 months during which the terms of separation are negotiated. They can afford to wait and see."

webTitle: FTSE 100 buoyed by Shire deal and Citigroup figures

fields.standfirst: Investors in more positive mood after last week's Portuguese banking concerns
fields.body:
After last week's downbeat performance, leading shares bounced back with their biggest daily rise since the start of the month.

Helped by merger news as Shire said it was ready to recommend an offer from US group AbbVie and better than expected results from Citigroup, the FTSE 100 finished 55.97 points higher at 6746.14. At one point the index was on course for its best daily performance since April, before a touch of profit taking set in. But on the whole, investors were in a better mood after last week's uncertainty, prompted by financial difficulties at Portuguese bank Espirito Santo and fears of possible contagion elsewhere.

Chris Beauchamp, market analyst at IG said:

So another stock market dip appears to have been consigned to the dustbin of history. On Bastille Day traders across the globe have displayed a little of the ardour that so animated those that stormed the infamous prison, while banishing any thoughts of beleaguered Portuguese banks to the back of their mind. Shire's coy dalliance with AbbVie has resulted in the UK firm agreeing to a takeover, and it seems that all concerned are quite contented with the outcome.

Among the risers, Shire added 33p to £49.03 after the latest AbbVie developments, while Barclays was 1.7p better at 209.6p following the Citigroup figures.

Mike Ashley's Sports Direct International rose 25p to 723p after it unveiled plans to launch in Australia and New Zealand in partnership with flash sales fashion retailer MySale.

Rolls-Royce rose 13p to £10.50 as Airbus announced at the Farnborough air show it would sell revamped versions of its A330 jet powered by the company's Trent 7000 engines.

Troubled Tesco added 6.35p to 284.45p as analysts at Cantor Fitzgerald moved from sell to buy and lifted its target price from 282p to 325p. Morrisons climbed 3.5p to 176.2p after it sold its Kiddicare children and baby products business for £2m to private equity firm Endless.

But Burberry lost 14p to £14.38 after a downbeat note from Berenberg analysts.

A fall in the prices of gold and silver hit precious metal miners, with Fresnillo falling 8.5p to 919.5p and Randgold Resources down 35p at £50.85.

Finally Quindell, the IT outsourcing and consultancy group which came under severe pressure in the wake of a negative report from Gotham City Research, jumped 30% to 235.5p after an upbeat trading statement. The company said first half revenue more than doubled to £355m and adjusted profits nearly tripled to £154m. Analysts at Cenkos said:

The update showed strong profit and loss delivery and an operating cash flow performance around £9m ahead of guidance. The outlook statement reaffirms the operating cash flow expectations for the third and fourth quarters. We have updated our model to reflect a shift in services mix towards industrial litigation and have increased our 2014 and 2015 EPS forecasts by 4% and 12% respectively. The encouraging comments on the balance sheet should support a re-rating back towards 400p in the short-term.

webTitle: Corporate inversion - moving the head office for tax purposes

fields.standfirst: International firms often shift their HQs to exploit tax regimes - a process particularly attractive at present to US companies
fields.body:
A corporate inversion occurs when a multinational group moves its notional head office, often for tax purposes, from its home jurisdiction to an overseas territory. The impact on operations is often minimal, with manufacturing activities and the markets in which it operates remaining unchanged.

However, combined with a web of crossborder transactions between companies owned by the same group, such inversions can play an important role in shifting profits within an international business to low-tax jurisdictions, boosting returns for shareholders.

Inversions are particularly attractive to US companies who are making substantial profits beyond American shores.

In part, this is because of the US taxman's unique approach to the taxation of multinationals. On the one hand, the tax treatment ofsuch firms has often driven overseas success because it encourages firms to make profits abroad. On the other,the tax regime leaves many of America's leading multinational groups – such as Apple and Amazon – straining to avoid repatriating profits .

At the end of last year AbbVie reported $21bn (£12.3bn) of "undistributed earnings" from overseas subsidiaries, up from $19.4bn the previous year – funds declared for US tax purposes that would be "indefinitely reinvested" abroad and should therefore not be taxed in America.

Shire itself carried out a corporate inversion in 2008 when it moved certain headquarter activities from Basingstoke, in Hampshire, to Dublin, as well as incorportating in Jersey. That move followed the then Labour government's efforts to strengthen HMRC's ability to capture the profits the UK multinationals were seeking to shift into overseas subsidiaries. Those efforts failed in the European courts.

Nonetheless, Shire did not reverse the move after the reforms were derailed. The company has since adopted what are widely viewed as some of the most generous tax treatments for multinationals and their overseas subsidiaries - measures which have helped make the UK a possible inversion base for many American groups.

Other US healthcare multinationals drawn recently to corporate inversion include Pfizer, although its takeover approach for AstraZeneca was ultimately rebuffed. More successful has been Medotronic, which last month agreed a $42.9bn deal to buy fellow medical device maker Covidien, a takeover that will relocate the combined group to the latter's Irish corporate home.

webTitle: Eurozone is weak and risks falling into deflation, IMF report warns

fields.standfirst: Euro area should repair bank balance sheets, step up reforms to boost jobs and the ECB should get ready for quantitative easing
fields.body:
The eurozone recovery is weak, its financial markets too fragmented, and the region risks falling into deflation, the International Monetary Fund has warned.

The IMF urged members to shore up the single currency bloc, including repairing bank balance sheets and stepping up reforms to boost employment. It repeated a recommendation that the European Central Bank should be ready for quantitative easing should inflation stay too low.

The Washington-based body concluded after its latest visit to the region that the euro area recovery was taking hold and action by national politicians and the ECB had helped boost investor confidence. But the euro-skeptic outcome of the European elections posed risks to the single market and the economic recovery was "neither robust nor sufficiently strong".

"The recovery is weak and uneven. Inflation has been too low for too long, financial markets are still fragmented, and structural gaps persist: these hinder rebalancing and substantial reductions in debt and unemployment," said the report.

It was completed in June, before troubles at one of Portugal's biggest banks sparked the latest bout of jitters in financial markets. The suspension of shares in Banco Espírito Santo last week prompted panic selling on both sides of the Atlantic amid concerns it would lead to a wider run on the eurozone's debt-ridden banking sector.

While markets have recouped some of their losses following reassurances from policymakers that the problems are contained, analysts said last week's turbulence was a wake-up call over unresolved problems.

The IMF highlighted "lingering damage" from the crisis, such as high unemployment, particularly among young people, and said that activity and investment were yet to return to pre-downturn levels. Growth was unevenly spread across countries and the flow of credit to businesses in stressed economies was contracting.

"Weakness in banks' balance sheets and uncertainty about their quality are contributing to fragmentation, constraining the ability and willingness of banks to support credit and investment," the IMF said.

The fund added that inflation was worryingly low and deflation a real risk, prompting a raft of policies from the ECB to avoid the region tipping into it.

"Risks to growth are still tilted to the downside. With limited policy space in the near term, further negative shocks – either domestic or external – could undermine financial market sentiment, halt the recovery, and push the economy into lower inflation and even deflation," the IMF said.

It painted a long road to full recovery. Growth was expected to accelerate only a little next year, to 1.5% from 1.1% in 2014 – a slight downgrade from April's prediction of 1.2% growth this year. That outlook compares with the IMF's forecast for the UK economy to grow 2.9% this year and for the US to expand 2%.

Inflation in the eurozone was forecast to remain below the ECB's target of around 2%. The IMF predicts inflation of 0.7% this year and 1.2% in 2015.

It recommended that policymakers focus on three areas to strengthen the recovery: supporting demand, repairing balance sheets and advancing structural reforms.

"Such policies would help mitigate risks to the recovery and reduce spillovers from low growth and low inflation to the rest of the world," it added.

It welcomed actions so far by the ECB and said it was reassuring the central bank had expressed willingness to do more if inflation remains too low. Such action should include asset purchases, known as quantitative easing, in the IMF's view.

webTitle: Russia withdraws delegates from Farnborough air show

fields.bodyText: Russia's deputy prime minister has told his country's defence delegates to withdraw from the Farnborough International Airshow and return home after being snubbed by the British government over the Ukraine conflict. The diplomatic incident came at the opening of the aerospace and defence industry's major sales fair in Hampshire and followed the UK government's efforts to actively discourage Russian attendance at the show. This year's event is marked by high-profile visits from cabinet members including David Cameron who attended the opening day yesterday. In a post on his twitter feed, Dmitry Rogozin, who heads Russia's defence sector as deputy prime minister, said: "I recommend our delegation to wind up its participation in the show and return home." The UK government traditionally invites representatives from selected foreign governments to attend Farnborough as its guests, but this year said: "Due to Russian actions in Ukraine, no representatives from the Russian government have been issued [government] invitations to Farnborough." It added: "The government has also taken clear action to remove Russia from the list of countries eligible to use open general export licences, in order to discourage Russian attendance at [the show] … no foreign government representatives attending [Farnborough] as guests of [the government] will be escorted around the Russian pavilion by officials." At Farnborough, however, representatives of the Russian state-owned arms firm Rosoboronexport appeared to be ignoring Rogozin's outburst and the hostility of the British government. One Rosoboronexport representative, who did not want to be named, said: "We saw [the Rogozin tweet]. We have not had an order [to leave] so we stay." He added that the show had been as busy "as normal" for the company. While Russian government officials may have struggled to enter the show, its state-owned defence companies have not been barred from exhibiting at the privately owned event and were out in force. They ranged from Rosoboronexport, which supplied attack helicopters and grenade launchers to Bashar al-Assad's regime in Syria, to the United Aircraft Corporation, which makes the MiG fighter jet, and Sputnik Insurance Centre, which says it is "one of the leading Russian insurers of rocket and space equipment". British officials are not taking their guests to meet Russian companies, although that did not appear to have cut off meetings between Russian representatives and other governments. The Guardian witnessed a four-strong delegation dressed in South African armed forces uniforms being escorted to the Rosoboronexport chalet on Farnborough airfield. According to the Rosoboronexport website, the company is "the exclusive state intermediary, entitled to supply the world market with the whole range of permitted arms exports and military equipment made by the enterprises of the military-industrial complex of Russia". Rosoboronexport has provided the Syrian government with the bulk of the tanks, fighters, missiles and helicopters used in a civil war that has claimed more than 170,000 lives, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute. Russians at the show complain that the UK declined visa requests for government officials and delegates from commercial companies, meaning they are not only barred from the airfield but also cannot enter the country and attend the side meetings that take place during the evenings at surrounding hotels. A Home Office spokesman would not say whether the UK government had declined visa requests from Russian delegates. He said: "Every visa application is considered in line with the immigration rules and on its individual merits." A spokesman for the Foreign Office said: "Farnborough International Airshow is a commercial event run by Farnborough International Ltd. The government plays no part in determining which companies are invited to exhibit. It is a commercial matter for the organisers to whom they sell exhibition space". On Monday, Cameron announced that Britain will invest £1.1bn in defence equipment such as surveillance aircraft, to enable it to better respond to threats including terrorism and cyber attacks. Britain has cut defence spending by about 8% over the last four years. However, the new investment, which is being funded from savings made by the Ministry of Defence, includes £800m for intelligence and surveillance equipment. The UK government action does not affect Russian businesses exhibiting at the show. This year a Russian state-owned arms firm, which supplied attack helicopters and grenade launchers to the Syrian regime, is exhibiting fighter jets. The Farnborough show is a major biennial event in the aerospace industry, in which official defence delegations study the latest military hardware and huge companies compete for sales. Each year the airline groups Boeing and Airbus compete not just for new orders but also for which company can make the most noteworthy announcements. Airbus landed the first blow in that traditional battle on Monday with the launch of its eagerly awaited, fuel-efficient upgrade to its long-haul A330 passenger jet, the A330neo. The plane, which is viewed as a direct competitor to Boeing's 787 Dreamliner and is powered by British Rolls-Royce engines, cuts fuel consumption by 14% per seat, according to Airbus. Deliveries of the revamped aircraft start in late 2017. The Airbus Group chief executive, Tom Enders, vowed to "keep the A330 flying high for many more years to come". Airbus has sold about 1,300 A330s since its launch in 1993, of which the vast majority are still in service. Airbus estimates that the A330neo could sell more than 1,000 units. In the absence of new technologies or revolutionary materials – such as lightweight carbon composites used in the new fuel-efficient planes – the launch of a brand new passenger jet is not envisaged for a further five to seven years. This has forced Airbus and Boeing to modernise current models, such as the US group's 777X, a new version of its jumbo jet that seats between 350 and 450 passengers. Airbus and Boeing are also revamping their medium-haul A320 and 737 planes, respectively. Airbus also announced that International Airlines Group, parent of British Airways and Spain's Iberia, had converted 20 A320neo options into a firm order, for delivery in 2018 and 2019. IAG indicated that it had received a substantial discount on each plane's list price of about $103m (£60m).

webTitle: Wonga appoints chairman with blue-chip financial credentials

fields.bodyText: The controversial cuddly puppets used in advertising by payday lender Wonga are being axed a part of a clean-up operation by its newly appointed chairman to improve the firm's reputation. Andy Haste, a former executive of blue-chip insurance companies, started his £500,000-a-year job as Wonga chairman on Monday with a blunt message that the company needed to change. "Wonga has understandably faced criticism and we know we need to repair our reputation and regain our right to be an accepted part of the financial service sector," he said. As well as eye-watering interest rates that can be equivalent to an annual 5,853%, Wonga has been accused of using cute puppets and catchy tunes in adverts aired during primetime children's TV. "The puppets are going and I think that is right," said Haste. "I am very aware of the criticism there has been of our advertising and marketing, which is one of my priorities to review." Insisting it was "not just about the puppets", he said: "We will be reviewing how we go to market across the piste, not just on TV." Haste, a 52-year-old City veteran who has led the centuries-old RSA insurance company as well as its rival AXA Sunlife, was a surprise choice for Wonga, founded in 2006 to offer short-term credit at sky-high rates. The UK's biggest payday lender has been without a permanent chief executive or chairman since its co-founder Errol Damelin quit as chairman in June last month. Damelin's departure, seven months after he stood down as chief executive, came just before the financial regulator ordered the payday lender to pay £2.6m in compensation for misleading customers by issuing letters to struggling borrowers under the name of fake legal firms. The Financial Conduct Authority said Wonga had been guilty of "unfair and misleading debt collection practices" after it emerged the lender had made up the companies to threaten legal action against customers. The Law Society has called for a criminal investigation but Haste said Wonga had not been contacted by police. "As of today we are not under criminal investigation and our whole focus is working with our regulator to pay compensation to customers in a timely manner." Wonga has also been attacked for "legal loansharking", uniting MP Stella Creasy and the Archbishop of Canterbury in condemnation of the high cost of its loans. Last week the Church of England announced it had ended its indirect investment in Wonga, a holding that had "embarrassed" and "irritated" the Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, who had said he wanted to "compete Wonga out of existence" by boosting credit unions. Asked whether Wonga could ever become a firm the Church would choose to invest in, Haste said: "I would be absolutely very happy to meet with the archbishop or anyone on his team to discuss those issues, to hear their concerns, to outline the programme of change we have at Wonga and where appropriate make changes as a result." Citizens Advice chief executive Gillian Guy said: "Cartoon characters promoting payday lending send the wrong message to borrowers. Years of debt are not cuddly or jovial, but instead are tough and distressing. It is good that one of the biggest payday lenders has come to its senses." The company declined to confirm whether it will end its sponsorship of Newcastle United football team. A spokesman said: "I don't want to prejudge the chairman. It is day one and we continue to be a proud sponsor of Newcastle United." Wonga has never disclosed how much it paid to have its name emblazoned on Newcastle's black and white shirts, but the four-year deal that began in the 2013-14 season is thought to be worth £8m. Haste expects Wonga's business and profits to shrink when a new cap on the industry's charges – to be announced on Tuesday – comes into force. "It is inevitable and understandable and accepted by our shareholders that in the near term we will likely be a smaller and less profitable business." The expected restrictions on overall charges, including interest rates and fees, are part of a wider clampdown on payday lenders that began this month with restrictions on the number of times loans can be rolled over or extended, and rules preventing firms making more than two unsuccessful attempts to take cash directly from customer's bank accounts. Many smaller payday lenders have already been forced out of the market because tougher regulation has made it harder and more expensive to operate. Haste said the company's priorities included a review of customers to ensure it is only lending to people "who can reasonably afford to repay their loans", and ensuring transparent lending, which he said would "lead to a tightening of Wonga's lending criteria". He said Wonga, which operates in nine countries with 4 million customers, could increase its profits in the medium term by repairing its reputation.

webTitle: Drax surges 5% after winning court ruling against government

fields.standfirst: High Court says Drax second unit eligible for subsidy, reversing government decision
fields.body:
Drax has won a High Court judgement against the government over subsidies for its power station units.

The company, presently converting its units from coal to biomass, said in April that the department of energy and climate change (DECC) had unexpectedly ruled its second unit was not eligible for a new - and higher - subsidy. This seemingly went against an initial decision.

Now the high court has ruled the second unit was indeed eligible for a so-called investment contract and the DECC ruling must be quashed and the matter resubmitted to DECC for reconsideration. DECC has been given leave to appeal. Analyst Angelos Anastasiou at Whitman Howard said:

This is a positive announcement, stating that the initial judgement deeming Drax's second unit ineligible for this subsidy must be quashed. If confirmed in the appeal, this would be good news for Drax, as on the day of the original announcement (23 April), Drax's shares fell 13.1% from 756.5p to 657.5p.

Following the court decision, Drax has jumped 36.5p to 716.5p.

webTitle: Burberry falls back on earnings worries

fields.standfirst: Following shareholder revolt on pay, luxury group's shares slide after downbeat note
fields.body:
Following a revolt by Burberry's shareholders over the pay package for new chief executive Christopher Bailey, the luxury goods group is under the cosh again, this time from the stock market.

Its shares have slipped 20p to £14.32 in what is otherwise a fairly upbeat FTSE 100, not helped by downbeat note from Berenberg. The bank's analyst John Guy issued a hold note with a £15.50 price target, saying:

On a PE-relative basis, Burberry is below its seven-year average, which may appear harsh given the underlying resilience of the top line. However, the risk of lacklustre earnings leverage persists to 2017 due to currency headwinds in 2015, the loss of Japanese profit associated with the licence termination from June 2015, incremental costs on the back of the roll-out of the Japanese global product offering and gross margin dilution as the Beauty sales footprint expands.
Currency is the principal headline earnings dilutor in 2015. According to our estimates, Burberry has around 50% operating expense exposure to sterling and does not hedge translational sales. The recent sterling appreciation from May to July has resulted in an additional £15m negative retail/wholesale EBIT effect, taking the 2015 total impact to £55m should spot rates remain at constant levels. Moreover, there is no change to expectations of a £10m decrease to licence revenues. We believe that recently appointed chief executive Christopher Bailey has the commercial acumen and creative credentials to take the Burberry brand into its next phase of profitable growth. However, we acknowledge that the path to operational excellence may be harder to navigate against the backdrop of incremental cost pressure (Japan, digital-related investments, costs associated with Chinese ex-franchise store renovations and the Beauty roll out).

webTitle: Co-op Bank chairman joins Allied Irish Bank

fields.standfirst: Richard Pym will start on 13 October, while the current AIB chairman David Hodgkinson, is due to retire in December
fields.body:
Veteran banker Richard Pym has been appointed chairman of Allied Irish Bank, the lender that received a €21bn (£16.7bn) bailout from the Irish taxpayer.

Pym will take up his duties on 13 October, while the current AIB chairman David Hodgkinson, is due to retire in December. Pym, a seasoned operator with a reputation for steadying banks in trouble, will stand down as chairman of the Co-op Bank on 1 October, having announced his departure in May.

Pym arrived at the Co-op Bank in June 2013 to calm the waters, after its debt was demoted to junk status and its chief executive quit. He is said to believe that his work is done and takes the view that the Co-op Bank's corporate governance has greatly improved.

"It has been a privilege to be part of the team involved in the rescue and turnaround of the Co-operative Bank," he said in a statement. "There are only a handful of institutions which hold a special place in British society and which stand worthy of the type of exceptional measures that have been undertaken at this bank."

Pym trained as an accountant and has decades of experience in banking. He was a well-regarded chief executive of Alliance & Leicester and went on to chair Bradford & Bingley bank after its share price collapsed at the height of the financial crisis. This experience made him an obvious choice to chair UK Asset Resolution, the government-owned bad bank that holds the toxic assets of Northern Rock and Bradford & Bingley, a role that he will retain once he starts at AIB.

With a reputation for careful decision-making, he began his career in retail, spending time at the Burton Group in the 1980s working with Sir Stuart Rose. He has also chaired Halfords and the British Land Company. Ireland's finance minister, Michael Noonan, welcomed Pym's appointment to AIB in what he said was an important time for the bank as it continues on the road to recovery.

"Mr Pym has a wealth of experience in the UK banking sector and I am confident that he we will prove to be a strong Chairman of AIB Group plc," Noonan said.

Pym said: "I look forward to contributing to the progress that has already been made in rebuilding a strong bank. Irish taxpayers have made considerable sacrifices in supporting the banking system and I am very conscious of my responsibilities in that regard."

webTitle: Tullow Oil slips after disappointing result in Ethiopia

fields.standfirst: Exploration well fails to find commercial oil and will be plugged and abandoned
fields.body:
The rollercoaster ride at Tullow Oil continues as the exploration and production group reported a disappointing outcome from Ethiopia.

The company's shares have slipped 1.5p to 788.5p after it said the Gardim-1 exploration well had failed to encounter commercial oil. The well will be plugged and abandoned. Tullow will now target other prospects in the licence area. Exploration director Angus McCoss said:

We have now drilled two independent wildcat wells in the Chew Bahir basin, neither of which encountered commercial oil. Having gained valuable data.... we look forward to the next phase of our exploration campaign in Ethiopia.

Earlier this month Tullow pleased the market with a small Arctic discovery, just a day after unveiling a $415m write-off relating to disappointing results in Mauritania, Norway and, yes, Ethopia.

webTitle: FTSE 100 recovers with Sports Direct leading the way on Australian deal

fields.standfirst: Mike Ashley's retailer up 4% after unveiled partnership with online group MySale
fields.body:
Leading shares have made a bright start to the week after the recent dip, which was partly due to worries about the financial state of Portugal's Espirito Santo bank and the fear of contagion spreading further afield.

After that decline, investors appear to be bargain hunting, which has lifted the FTSE 100 50.30 points to 6740.47. Alastair McCaig, market analyst at IG, said:

After a couple of days off, the worries and fears of the previous week appear to have been consigned to history. Traders comforted with a decent correction and the perception of better value start the latest round of 'buy on the dip' investment. It's a slow start to the economic calendar today, however, with Tuesday morning's German ZEW confidence figures looking to be the first highlight of the week; unfortunately they were calibrated a little too early for the country's World Cup exploits to boost anybody's morale.

On that sporting theme, Mike Ashley's Sports Direct International is leading the way, up 29.5p to 727.5p after it unveiled plans to launch in Australia and New Zealand in partnership with flash sales fashion retailer MySale. It will also open four stores in the region.

Close behind was Shire, up 124p to £49.94 as the pharmaceutical group said it was ready to accept a £53.20 or £31bn offer from US group AbbVie.

Rolls-Royce has risen 15p to £10.52 as Airbus announced at the Farnborough air show it would sell revamped versions of its A330 jet powered by the company's Trent 7000 engines.

Troubled Tesco has added 5.55p to 283.65p as analysts at Cantor Fitzgerald moved from sell to buy and lifted its target price from 282p to 325p. Analyst Mike Dennis said:

This [upgrade] reflects our view that Tesco UK is 35% undervalued compared to its UK peers and that Tesco's reconfiguration of its UK operations could, in our view, be successful in recapturing the shifting customer base in retail.
More importantly, we believe Tesco might need to consider some box cutting, in terms of reducing space in hypermarkets. In the meantime we see Tesco's on-line and convenience sales growing ahead of the market, while the reduction in capital intensity in core stores should lead to improved free cashflow, dividend cover and return on capital employed. Tesco UK is, in our view, on a distressed rating of 8.1 times 2015 enterprise value/earnings before interest and tax, a 35% discount to J Sainsbury and Morrisons. The first half of 2015 could mark the low point for the UK operations and the new chief financial officer Alan Stewart could, in our view, bring some renewed confidence to forecasts. Hence, we expect Tesco's UK trading margin to stabilise around 4.3% plus and UK sales growth to return in 2015.

But safe haven utilities slipped back, with SSE down 6p at £15.41 and Severn Trent down 5p at £19.15.

webTitle: Lindt expands in America with Russell Stover Candies acquisition

fields.standfirst: Swiss chocolatier famous for its Easter bunnies buys US firm whose pralines were eaten by Tom Hanks in Forrest Gump
fields.body:
The Swiss chocolate maker Lindt is buying the American candy company Russell Stover for an undisclosed price.

Russell Stover was founded by a husband and wife in Denver in 1923 and is now the US's third largest confectionery company with sales of $500m (£292m) and 2,700 employees. A popular choice for Valentine's Day wooers and Christmas gift givers, its pralines had their status in American life cemented by their appearance in the 1994 movie Forrest Gump, when the lead character, played by Tom Hanks, quoted his mother: "My mama always said: 'Life is like a box of chocolates – you never know what you are gonna get.'"

The deal is the biggest ever acquisition for Lindt, best known for its foil-covered chocolate balls, reindeers and Easter bunnies. The Kilchberg-based company said the deal meant it would exceed $1.5bn in turnover in North America in 2015. Lindt already has a presence in the North American market, through Ghirardelli, one of the country's oldest chocolate makers, which traces its roots back to the mid-19th century and was bought by Lindt in 1998.

Ernst Tanner, Lindt's chairman and chief executive, said: "This biggest and most important strategic acquisition to date in Lindt & Sprüngli's history is a unique opportunity for us to expand our North American chocolate business and will greatly enhance the group's status in the world's biggest overall chocolate marketplace."

webTitle: America's six largest banks prepare to update investors

fields.standfirst: Banks expected to show quarterly revenue declined 5.6% from previous year and that they have been affected by poor trading
fields.body:
America's biggest banks will update investors this week amid expectations that the financial services sector has been hit once more by lacklustre lending, poor trading and the soaring cost of legal expenses tied to a series of fines and investigations.

The six largest US banks – Bank of America, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan Chase, Morgan Stanley and Wells Fargo – are expected to show quarterly revenue declined by 5.6% from the previous year, according to the analyst estimates.

Profits are expected to drop as banks face a tough comparison with a strong second quarter last year.

The results come as regulators are negotiating settlements with some of the banks and continue to investigate others over a variety of issues.

Citigroup, which reports on Friday, is believed to be close to a $7bn (£4.1bn) settlement over the sale of risky mortgages in the runup to the financial crisis. The justice department reached a similar agreement with JP Morgan, reporting Tuesday, last year.

The justice department is also in talks with Bank of America about alleged wrongdoing in its mortgage business ahead of the crisis.

The talks with the bank, which reports on Wednesday, have apparently stalled. Reuters reported earlier this month that the attorney general, Eric Holder, had refused to meet Bank of America chief executive Brian Moynihan because the two sides remain too far apart.

Alongside legal woes the banks are also experiencing continued problems on their trading desks, once the main driver of growth, now held back by new regulations aimed at tamping down excessive risk taking and lack of appetite among investors.

Foreign exchange and fixed income trading revenues have fallen at the investment banks this year.

Bond trading income declined by 11% at Goldman Sachs in the first quarter and investors will be watching closely for signs of improvement when the bank reports on Tuesday.

Wells Fargo, the US's biggest lender, kicked off the latest bank results reporting season last Friday.

The bank has never been a big trader and has instead concentrated on commercial and consumer lending. It also managed to avoid the regulatory woes of its rivals.

Wells posted a 3.8% rise in net income, ahead of expectations, but investors were disappointed by a slip in lending profitability and a slowdown in its cost-cutting programme.

A bank analyst at FBR Capital Markets, Paul Miller, described Wells' results as so-so but said there were still many positive signs in its business and it was likely to outperform its peers. "I don't think the banks can earn what they are expected to earn relative to their valuations," he said.

Miller said investors had largely discounted the fines some of the banks still face and were more interested in what they were likely to do in 2016 than their historic problems.

He added that the banks' fixed income and equity desks were still performing poorly and the still sluggish economy remained a drag on the sector. "What they need is jobs, jobs, jobs," he said. "They need the economy to pick up."

webTitle: Why Australian voters care more about jobs than fixing the budget

fields.standfirst: It will be hard for Tony Abbott and Joe Hockey to sell benefits of a fast return to surplus if employment remains as it is
fields.body:
The labour force figures released last week showed Australia’s employment situation remains fragile and somewhat disconnected from the broader picture of economic growth. It hints at a “jobless recovery” and also demonstrates that while economic growth may improve the budget bottom line and “fix the budget”, that does not mean Australian workers will necessarily reap the benefits.

The “jobless recovery” was a big feature of the 1990s recession. While that recession was deep and horrific, the recovery was extremely strong. Through 1993 and 1994 Australia’s GDP grew by over 4%. But as the economy in Australia improved, employment growth lagged well behind:

While employment growth did catch up to GDP growth for a year or so in 1995, it then fell, even while the economy as a whole continued to go gangbusters.

This is somewhat unusual. There is supposed to be a nice link between GDP growth and employment. There’s even an economic “law” to describe the relationship – Okun’s Law – which charts the relationship between GDP growth and changes in the unemployment rate.

Like most economic laws, it’s more a guide than a fast rule, but historically it has been a good guide.

It suggests that for the unemployment rate in Australia to stay steady, GDP needs to grow by roughly 3%. If it grows faster than that, the unemployment rate is expected to fall (and vice versa). Using data from the past 30 years, an annual GDP growth of 4% would on average see the unemployment rate fall by 0.3 percentage points in a year, whereas if GDP grew by only 2%, the unemployment rate would be expected to rise by around 0.5 percentage points.

Over the past three years however, for whatever level of GDP growth was achieved, the unemployment rate performed worse than would be expected on average (the red dots in the above chart).

For example in the 12 months to March 2014, GDP grew by 3.2% (in trend terms), but the unemployment rate, rather than stay flat or slightly decline as would be expected, rose by 0.4 percentage points.

When we compare employment growth and GDP growth since 2005, we can see that a split between the two has occurred since March 2011:

Even in 2012, when the economy was growing by nearly 4%, employment growth was sluggish.

The United States, on the other hand, is experiencing the opposite – its economy is limping along with growth around 1.5% to 2%, and yet its employment situation is performing much better than expected. The White House announced in its “mid-session review” of the budget that it expects the unemployment rate to fall from its current rate of 6.1% to 5.6% despite weak GDP growth.

A major factor that has hurt our employment growth has been the exchange rate.

In the two years to March 2011, when the split between GDP and employment growth occurred, the Australian dollar rose 50% in value against the US dollar, and by 33% against the basket of currencies in the “trade weighted index”. By contrast in that time the US dollar fell by around 15% against the currencies of its major trading partners:

And while our dollar has fallen somewhat in the past 18 months, it remains around 16% above its 30-year average.

That high dollar has massively hindered the export-exposed industries in the non-mining sector – as our exports have been expensive and our imports cheap.

The disconnect between economic growth and the employment sector is also another example of the different type of mining boom we are experiencing. As we saw in the March GDP figures, the mining sector held up strongly on the back of a strong growth in exports, but this type of mining activity does not employ many workers.

To give an example of how stark the change has been, in May 2012, engineering job vacancies were the fourth most common vacancy; in May 2014, they were the 22nd most common.

May 2014 saw the fewest job vacancies for engineers recorded by the Department of Employment since it began collating such data in January 2006:

But the employment sluggishness is odd not just because of the disconnect with the overall economy. The oddness is that while the weak growth has occurred for a long time, it has never completely fallen off a cliff.

If we look at the difference between the growth of the labour force (ie including those working and those looking for work) with the growth of employment, the annual growth of the labour force has now been faster than annual employment growth for 35 straight months:

That is second longest streak since the ABS began calculating monthly employment data in 1978. It means the growth in jobs is not keeping up with the growth in people looking for them.

But while this weak jobs growth has been historically long, it has not been historically awful. Usually such a bleak period of employment growth would have seen sharp declines in employment growth:

This time, instead of being terrible it has just meandered along like a boxer who has taken one too many punches to the head, but who somehow stays on his feet.

This meandering employment growth also indicates the difference between the budget and the economy. Whereas in the US, the White House is warning that despite solid employment recovery, the weaker than expected GDP growth will hurt tax revenue, in Australia, stronger than expected GDP growth through exports could see a much improved revenue side of the budget – through a better than expected corporate tax take.

So we could have a case where the budget bottom line is improved, but employment remains stagnant.

Paul Keating suffered greatly in the 1996 election because (among other things) despite improved GDP growth and an improved budget position, unemployment took much longer to recover. For most people, GDP growth is largely irrelevant – you don’t pay your rent with the amount of GDP per capita you supposedly have.

For most, the “economy” is synonymous with “employment”. And given how often Joe Hockey and Tony Abbott have argued that “you can’t fix the economy unless you fix the budget”, it will be hard for them to sell the benefits of a faster return to surplus if the employment situation remains as it is.
